content.question:
An aerodrome on the coast (Faro, Portugal) reported the following METAR:
LPFR 070650Z 26015KT 0100FG VV/// 05/05 Q1006
What type of fog can you expect in Faro?

key_points: Faro (LPFR) is a coastal airport which is prone to advection fog
Advection fog is formed by the advection of warm, moist air over a cold surface – the air mass is cooled from below giving rise to an inversion
The surface can be land or sea and it can appear by day or night
learning.explanation: Faro (LPFR) is a coastal airport which is prone to advection fog. Advection fog is formed by the advection of warm, moist air over a cold surface – the air mass is cooled from below giving rise to an inversion. The surface can be land or sea and it can appear by day or night. Conditions necessary for advection fog to form WIND SPEEDS. Up to 15 kts to move the air (may be stronger over sea – up to 20 kts). Wind speeds over 5 kts are sufficient for advection fog formation, but the speeds of around 15 kts provide the conditions for maximum vertical development of advection fog. COLD SURFACE. Colder than the dew point of the air moving over it – to ensure condensation. HUMID AIR. High relative humidity – so that relatively little cooling is required to produce saturation and subsequent condensation. TEMPERATURE DIFFERENCE. The greater the temperature difference between the warmer air and the colder ground, the greater the likelihood of fog formation.

An aerodrome on the coast (Faro, Portugal) reported the following METAR:

What change is likely, on its own, to produce an improvement in visibility above the limits stated for fog?

options.B: A cold front crossing the area.

key_points: Note: This question has two correct answers, both "Diurnal solar heating" and "A cold front crossing the area" would dissipate the advection fog in the METAR
Early feedback and knowledge leaned on the side of "Diurnal solar heating", but most recent feedback shows the cold front to be the correct answer
See the comments for the most recent feedback
learning.explanation: Note: This question has two correct answers, both "Diurnal solar heating" and "A cold front crossing the area" would dissipate the advection fog in the METAR. Early feedback and knowledge leaned on the side of "Diurnal solar heating", but most recent feedback shows the cold front to be the correct answer. See the comments for the most recent feedback. UPDATE: The Hungarian CAA have approved an appeal based on this question (which said that two correct answers were present), stating, "The cold front is the right option, because clearance occurs with a change of air mass, or less commonly with an increase in surface wind. The term "on its own” means the weather phenomena associated with cold front. Of course not the definition of cold front will improve the visibility, but the phenomena. Hovewer diurnal solar heating can also be a correct answer." We think that the cold front and diurnal solar heating are both perfectly correct, so we hope that they have removed this question from the database now. If this comes up in an exam, you may appeal it, quoting the Hungarian CAA above if necessary. Advection fog is formed by the advection of warm, moist air over a cold surface – the air mass is cooled from below giving rise to an inversion. The surface can be land or sea and it can appear by day or night. Most commonly, the dissipation of advection fog is by a change of air mass, replacing the moist air with dry air. For example, in this question, the movement of a cold front would mean that the new air is not the same air than cooled overnight close to the ground, and so the advection fog will dissipate. However, sometimes solar heating on the land is sufficient to raise the temperature to the condensation point and the fog evaporates.

content.question: An air mass containing St and Sc clouds is cooling as it is lifted over high ground. Which of the following will happen to the concentration of water droplets or ice particles?

options.C: The concentration will remain the same.
options.D: The concentration will remain the same, and their sizes will increase.

key_points: Air contains a certain amount of water held in vapour form - its humidity
Warmer air can hold more water vapour than cooler air can, so the humidity is often measured relative to how much that parcel of air can hold

If an air mass gets cooler and the relative humidity passes 100% (past the amount it can hold), the excess water will begin to condense as droplets (or depose into ice crystals directly if cold enough)
learning.explanation: Air contains a certain amount of water held in vapour form - its humidity. Warmer air can hold more water vapour than cooler air can, so the humidity is often measured relative to how much that parcel of air can hold. If an air mass gets cooler and the relative humidity passes 100% (past the amount it can hold), the excess water will begin to condense as droplets (or depose into ice crystals directly if cold enough). This forms clouds, when the temperature drops below the dew point as air rises. As the clouds are being forced to rise by the terrain (and we have not been told that precipitation has yet begun to fall), the airmass is cooling, and the colder air will not be able to hold as much moisture in vapour form, so more and more of the stored vapour will condense into droplets or ice crystals (depending on the freezing level). As this is unlikely to make the current droplets/crystals larger due to the rate of coalescence usually being lower than the rate of droplet formation, the only possible correct answer is that the concentration of droplets/crystals in the cloud will increase.

content.question: When two humid, but yet unsaturated air masses with different temperatures mix, the result can be...

options.A: cloud dissipation, because the saturation humidity of mixed air exceeds the combined humidity.
options.B: onset of intense adiabatic processes with formation of CB clouds and thunderstorms.
options.C: cloud formation (or frontal fog), because the combined humidity exceeds the saturation humidity at mixing temperature.
options.D: onset of heavy precipitation leading to dissipation of clouds within the mixing air masses.

key_points: CLOUD FORMATION Cloud is formed by air being lifted and cooled adiabatically until the water vapour condenses out as water droplets
In other words, when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into visible water droplets or ice crystals
For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated => unable to hold all the water it contains in vapour form, so it starts to condense into a liquid or solid form
learning.explanation: CLOUD FORMATION Cloud is formed by air being lifted and cooled adiabatically until the water vapour condenses out as water droplets. In other words, when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into visible water droplets or ice crystals. For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated => unable to hold all the water it contains in vapour form, so it starts to condense into a liquid or solid form. The height at which this occurs is called the condensation level - it is also the height of the cloud base. The condensation level is the height at which the rising air, cooling adiabatically, has cooled to the dew point temperature. Any further ascent and cooling will result in condensation and the formation of cloud. There are two ways by which saturation is reached. (a) By increasing the water content in the air, e.g. through evaporation, to a point where the air can hold no more. (b) By cooling the air so that it reaches its dew point - this is the temperature at which condensation occurs, and is unable to 'hold' any more water. => Therefore, we can conclude that 2 unsaturated parcels of air will form a cloud when they cool down to the dew point temperature, becoming saturated => and condensation starts.

Steam fog is typically up to 500 feet thick and may drift inland. The fog can be persistent and up to 500 feet thick - may drift inland. Forms in conditions of no wind or very light winds. content.question: Freezing fog consists of:

key_points: FREEZING FOG

Fog can form when moisture is added into the air or the air cools to a point that it becomes saturated
learning.explanation: FREEZING FOG. In its simplest sense, fog is a cloud near the ground that consists of tiny liquid water droplets. Fog can form when moisture is added into the air or the air cools to a point that it becomes saturated. Freezing fog occurs when fog forms in temperatures that are below freezing, and the tiny water droplets in the air remain as liquid. They become supercooled water droplets remaining liquid even though they are below freezing temperature. This occurs because liquid needs a surface to freeze upon. When droplets from freezing fog freeze onto surfaces, a white deposit of feathery ice crystals is formed. This is referred to as rime; rime is a characteristic of freezing fog and is often seen on vertical surfaces exposed to the wind.

content.question: Which of the following limits the upwards growth of stratiform clouds?

options.A: An inversion below the cloud top.
options.B: An inversion above the cloud top.
options.C: Adiabatic heating above the cloud top.
options.D: Adiabatic heating below the cloud top.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.04.01.03.02: Explain the influence of an inversion on the formation of stratus clouds. In the troposphere, inversions cause an incredibly stable layer of atmosphere, which reduces the upwards motion of cumuliform clouds, and limits the vertical extent of stratiform clouds completely. Stratiform clouds can form for many reasons, such as turbulence in the air causing mixing, orographic or frontal uplift, etc., but they always occur in a stable layer of atmosphere. When the air gets pushed up or mixed up enough to reach its dewpoint, the cloud base forms, and if the air is raised above this, then the cloud continues upwards as high as the air is pushed/mixed. An inversion, however, is much too stable, and any air moving into the inversion will either fall back out of the layer, as the layer is a lot warmer than the air below (preventing mixing of the air), or just warm up above the dewpoint and stop forming cloud. This means that stratiform clouds remain below an inversion in the atmosphere, and this limits their growth.

learning.explanation: Note: This is quite similar to question 501937, but with answers that are different enough to warrant a separate question here. We have some slightly conflicting feedback about wording for this one, so please let us know if you see either question in the exam, and what you can remember about them, thank you! RADIATION FOG. Caused by radiation of the earth’s heat at night, and the conductive cooling below dew point of the air in contact with the ground, in conditions of calm or very light wind and clear skies. Radiation fog occurs at night and early morning and usually does not last long after sunrise (about 30 minutes). Predominantly occurring in autumn and winter. The cooling of air close to the ground causes that air to drop below the temperature of the air just above it (which is not touching the ground), causing a very low-level inversion, known as a ground inversion. Inversions are very stable areas, and these ones in particular create radiation fog when the cold air inside the inversion drops below its dewpoint CONDITIONS NECESSARY FOR RADIATION FOG TO FORM Clear sky - increases the rate of terrestrial radiation and cooling of the ground. High relative humidity - little cooling will be enough to cause saturation and condensation into fog. Calm or very light wind – any heavier wind (above 8 kt) causes turbulent mixing of the lower air, breaking up the ground inversion, and lifting the fog into low stratus cloud. Surface - only occurs over land, because ground surface is a much better heat conductor than sea surface. To go through the options: "In the inversion layer there is a lot of turbulence, which causes the formation of fog." There is very little turbulence in an inversion layer. "The decrease of temperature with the height close to the surface is abnormally high." In a ground inversion, the air above the ground increases with height until the top of the inversion is reached, which is the opposite of this option. "The air cools down close to the ground, without any convection." Correct. The air in contact with the ground cools down by conduction, which makes the air close to the ground much colder than the air above it, this is an inversion, and when that air reaches its dew point, fog will form. "In the inversion layer the air is unstable, which allows significant cooling close to the ground. An inversion is always an absolutely stable layer of air.

One of the key differences in appearance between a towering cumulus and a cumulonimbus cloud is the size. A towering cumulus cloud is a large, white, fluffy cloud that can reach great heights, but it is not as tall and wide as a cumulonimbus cloud. Another difference is that a cumulonimbus cloud often has an anvil-shaped top, which is caused by the cloud reaching the upper limit of the troposphere and the winds spreading the top of the cloud out horizontally. Also, cumulonimbus clouds are more likely to produce thunderstorm and lightning than towering cumulus clouds.

content.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the relationship between moisture content, precipitation type and the resultant effects on visibility?

options.B: Visibility in a shower with blowing snow is better than in heavy rain.

learning.explanation: 050.05.02.01.08: Explain the relationship between moisture content and visibility during different types of winter precipitation (e.g. large vs small snowflakes). Moisture content and type of precipitation are the main factors of visibility during precipitation. For instance, rain has relatively good visibility, as the light is scattered a little through each raindrop, but they are relatively see through still. More importantly, rain is a very dense form of precipitation, as so there are less raindrops than for a snow shower of the same moisture content. Snow, therefore, has quite poor visibility, depending on the intensity of course. A light snow shower would still have better visibility than a heavy tropical rain shower. For this question, we should consider each option: A) "Visibility in precipitation with large snow flakes is worse than in rain." This is absolutely correct, snow flakes give worse visibility than rain. Large snowflakes are worse still, as they block more light. B) "Visibility in a shower with blowing snow is better than in heavy rain." Blowing snow is where the wind picks up the snow from the ground and the snow which falls during a snow shower, creating very low visibility indeed, as low as 1 metre visibility. Heavy rain is not as bad as this, so this is incorrect. C) "Visibility in heavy snow is better than in drizzle with small water droplets." I think it is quite obvious that visibility is very bad in heavy snow, and not nearly as bad in drizzle, so this is incorrect. D) "Regardless of the moisture content, the visibility in rain is worse than in snow." As discussed above, it is more difficult to see through snow, which is a much less dense form of precipitation, so takes up more space, and is also more opaque than rain. This is therefore incorrect.

Within these CB clouds, precipitation particles have the opportunity to grow larger due to the aggregation of ice crystals and supercooled water droplets, ultimately resulting in the formation of hail
When the size of these ice particles exceeds 5 mm, they are referred to as hailstones
learning.explanation: Hail is commonly associated with cumulonimbus (CB) clouds, which exhibit noticeable strong updrafts and downdrafts. Within these CB clouds, precipitation particles have the opportunity to grow larger due to the aggregation of ice crystals and supercooled water droplets, ultimately resulting in the formation of hail. When the size of these ice particles exceeds 5 mm, they are referred to as hailstones. As the hailstones continue to grow, they eventually reach a critical size that cannot be sustained by the upward air currents within the cloud. Consequently, they begin to fall from the cloud toward the ground. However, there is a possibility for hailstones to rise again if they are carried into an area with a strong updraft. This process can lead to the repeated aggregation of supercooled water droplets onto the hailstones, contributing to their further growth. This repeated cycle of aggregation and growth results in the layered structure of hailstones, resembling the layers of a cabbage or an onion. Additionally, the hailstone can also grow through sublimation, where water vapor in the cloud condenses directly onto the hailstone, further increasing its size.

learning.explanation: Unlike the Bergeron Process, where precipitation forms under supercooled conditions, the COALESCENCE PROCESS typically occurs within relatively warm clouds with tops warmer than -15C. As you can tell by the name of this process, the collision of falling and rising droplets is what allows them to grow large enough to fall to the ground as precipitation. In simple words, Cloud droplets of different sizes will fall at different velocities and will collide with droplets of different radii. If the collision is hard enough to overcome the surface tension between the two colliding droplets, coalescence will occur and result in a new and larger single droplet. This process of cloud-droplet growth is referred to as collision-coalescence. Warm-cloud rain results when the droplets attain a sufficient size to fall to the ground.

learning.explanation: Freezing precipitation occurs in the form of Freezing Rain (FZRA) or Freezing Drizzle (FZDZ). FREEZING PRECIPITATION. The conditions needed for freezing precipitation are quite specific. Generally, precipitation first falls from a cloud as snow. If it falls through warmer air before reaching the ground, it can melt and turn to rain droplets. If it then falls through cold air again before hitting the ground, the droplets can become supercooled (which means that they are still falling in liquid state, even though their temperature is below 0ºC). Freezing rain/drizzle is a rare type of liquid precipitation that strikes a surface and freezes almost instantly. Precipitation which contains large supercooled water droplets => Freezing Rain Precipitation which contains small supercooled water droplets => Freezing Drizzle

learning.explanation: PRECIPITATION. There are currently two theories governing the formation of these precipitation drops: BERGERON THEORY. It involves supercooled water droplets and explains how ice crystals grow at the expense of liquid cloud droplets within a mixed cloud. There are more water molecules surrounding the water droplets than there are surrounding the ice crystals. This occurs because the saturation vapor pressure over a water surface is greater than that over an ice surface at the same temperature. Some of the water droplets will turn to ice and will grow in size by sublimation of water vapour and collision with supercooled water droplets. The frozen droplets will be much heavier than the existing water droplets and drop out at the bottom of the cloud, either as snow or raindrops, depending on the temperature. Unlike the Bergeron Process, where precipitation forms under supercooled conditions, the COALESCENCE PROCESS typically occurs within relatively warm clouds with tops warmer than -15ºC. As you can tell by the name of this process, the collision of falling and rising droplets is what allows them to grow large enough to fall to the ground as precipitation.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The Bergeron-Findeisen process is mainly based on the difference of maximum vapour pressure over water and over ice of the same temperature.
options.B: At mid-latitudes the coalescence process is usually the initial process in the formation of precipitation.
options.C: In the tropics stratiform precipitation does not occur.

key_points: BERGERON THEORY
It involves supercooled water droplets and explains how ice crystals grow at the expense of liquid cloud droplets within a mixed cloud
There are more water molecules surrounding the water droplets than there are surrounding the ice crystals
learning.explanation: BERGERON THEORY. It involves supercooled water droplets and explains how ice crystals grow at the expense of liquid cloud droplets within a mixed cloud. There are more water molecules surrounding the water droplets than there are surrounding the ice crystals. This occurs because the saturation vapor pressure over a water surface is greater than that over an ice surface at the same temperature. Some of the water droplets will turn to ice and will grow in size by sublimation of water vapour and collision with supercooled water droplets. The frozen droplets will be much heavier than the existing water droplets and drop out at the bottom of the cloud, either as snow or raindrops, depending on the temperature. About other options: "At mid-latitudes the coalescence process is usually the initial process in the formation of precipitation." Incorrect as in mid-latitudes coalescence process produces only drizzle and or very light rain. "In the tropics stratiform precipitation does not occur." Incorrect as stratiform rainfall generally occurs more frequently in the tropics, yet convective rainfall accounts for most of the cumulative rainfall because it has a higher intensity. "The principle of the Bergeron-Findeisen process is mainly based on the difference in size of the cloud elements." Incorrect as it is based on ice crystal growth that occurs in mixed-phase clouds.

content.question: In cold clouds where ice crystals and cloud droplets coexist, most precipitation starts out as..

key_points: BERGERON PROCESS Describes the process of precipitation formation in the middle and high latitudes
Clouds form at altitudes where the temperatures are below the freezing point of water
In these clouds, water exists in its liquid form even though the temperatures are cold enough to freeze water
learning.explanation: BERGERON PROCESS Describes the process of precipitation formation in the middle and high latitudes. Clouds form at altitudes where the temperatures are below the freezing point of water. In these clouds, water exists in its liquid form even though the temperatures are cold enough to freeze water. Water that has a temperature below freezing but is still in a liquid state is called supercooled water. Ice crystals are found co-existing with the super-cooled water in cold clouds. When this occurs, the ice crystals will grow at the expense of the water droplets. At temperatures below freezing the saturation vapor pressure of ice is less than that over a droplet of water. This means that a water vapor gradient exists between the droplet and the ice. Water can evaporate off the droplet and deposit on the ice in response to the water vapor gradient. The droplet will dissipate in size while the ice crystal grows into a snow flake. Once the snow flake is large enough, it will fall to the surface. Thus, precipitation that falls in the middle and high latitudes starts out as snow. Whether it hits the surface as snow or rain depends on the temperature conditions through which the snowflake falls.

learning.explanation: STRATUS (ST) - are low-level layers with a fairly uniform base and grey or white colour. Its vertical extent may be from a few hundred feet up to several thousand feet. Stratus is usually accompanied by little to no rainfall but if it is thick enough, it can produce drizzle or light snow. When stratus is at its thinnest, the sun can be clearly seen through the stratus layer. Sometimes Stratus appears in the form of ragged patches. Stratus clouds often dissipate during daytime by direct heating of the cloud layer by solar absorption and subsequent reduction in the relative humidity.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which of the following diagrams represents a warm front?

key_points: The warm front slopes forward
The lighter, warmer, moist air is forced up and over the heavier, colder air, rising very gently along a slope of about 1:150
This gentle slope results in minimal vertical flow, leading to stratiform clouds and light to moderate continuous drizzle, rain, or snow along the warm front
learning.explanation: The warm front slopes forward. The lighter, warmer, moist air is forced up and over the heavier, colder air, rising very gently along a slope of about 1:150. This gentle slope results in minimal vertical flow, leading to stratiform clouds and light to moderate continuous drizzle, rain, or snow along the warm front. In contrast, the cold front slopes backward because the heavy, cold air forces itself underneath the warmer, lighter air. With a slope of between 1:50 and 1:80, the cold front is steeper than the warm front but still relatively gentle, causing stratiform clouds due to the gentle uplift. However, the cold front also has a bulging "cold nose" near the surface, creating an unstable area where warm, buoyant air lies beneath cold air. This instability triggers rapid vertical uplift, resulting in large cumuliform clouds.

key_points: WARM FRONT
Can be defined as warm air replacing cold air
The warm, less dense air is overtaking/displacing the cold air => warm air will ride up and over the denser cold air while advancing
learning.explanation: WARM FRONT. Can be defined as warm air replacing cold air. The warm, less dense air is overtaking/displacing the cold air => warm air will ride up and over the denser cold air while advancing. The air behind the warm front is warmer and moister than the air ahead of it (when the front passes, the air becomes warmer and more humid). The slope of the warm air is approximately 1:100 to 1:150. Warm front is slower than a cold front. The front moves at right angles to itself at a speed equal to 2/3 of the geostrophic interval measured along the front. The warm air is mostly stable, the clouds that form are mostly stratiform. As the warm front approaches, we typically see this sequence of clouds: Cl, CS, AS, NS. Cirrus CI: at FL250-350 as far as 600 NM ahead of the front. Cirrostratus CS: at FL200-250 gradually replace the Cl. Altostratus AS: at FL150-200 as the front gets closer. Nimbostratus NS: between 6000 - 8000 ft, approx. 150-200 NM away (in some cases up to 300 NM) until the front. Stratus ST or Stratocumulus SC: can be encountered below the NS Frontal FOG can sometimes be encountered 20-50 NM ahead of the frontal ground surface.

content.question: Which of the following statements about the weather at a stationary front is true?

options.A: Stationary fronts are accompanied by several thunderstorms along the front line, also called squall line.
options.B: Stationary fronts are accompanied by a cloud band and precipitation of varying intensity.
options.C: Stationary fronts are accompanied by a large cloud band with heavy precipitation.
options.D: Stationary fronts are generally not accompanied by clouds.

key_points: A STATIONARY front forms when a cold front or warm front stops moving
This happens when two masses of air are pushing against each other but neither is powerful enough to move the other
The situation can be described winds blowing parallel to the front instead of perpendicular can help it stay in place
learning.explanation: A STATIONARY front forms when a cold front or warm front stops moving. This happens when two masses of air are pushing against each other but neither is powerful enough to move the other. The situation can be described winds blowing parallel to the front instead of perpendicular can help it stay in place. The exact weather of a stationary front depends greatly on the characteristics of its constituent air masses - their moisture levels, for example - and the general instability of the local atmosphere. Often, however, conditions resemble those encountered along warm front weather: extensive cloudiness and showers. A wide area of precipitation can be expected on the cold-air side. Since there is little frontal movement, weather conditions are likely to be comparatively quiet, though longer lasting.

content.question: An aircraft is flying at 3000 ft in a layer of strato-cumulus cloud and experiences light icing.This icing intensifies as the aircraft crosses a mountain barrier whilst still in the cloud. This may be explained by..

options.A: orographic intensification as water vapour is added to the air from the Earth`s surface in mountainous areas.
options.B: the mixing of dry and moist air by turbulence or rotors at a low level, upwind of the mountain barrier.
options.C: orographic intensification as the air is forced to rise over the mountain barrier.
options.D: the condensation of water vapour on the leeward side parallel to the upper part of the ridge.

key_points: If flying around mountains, be extra cautious
The air being lifted up the mountain slopes by the wind (called orographic lifting) causes icing to be more intense than it is usual under identical conditions over low, flat terrain
It is known to produce moderate to severe icing conditions
learning.explanation: If flying around mountains, be extra cautious. The air being lifted up the mountain slopes by the wind (called orographic lifting) causes icing to be more intense than it is usual under identical conditions over low, flat terrain. It is known to produce moderate to severe icing conditions. Icing is greater over the ridges than over valleys and greater on the windward side than on the leeward side. The lifting of the cold unstable by the mountains results in the formation of more-or-less continuous supercooled clouds. Also, the orographically-induced updrafts permit the air to support larger cloud droplets than otherwise, so that the icing is more intense. Furthermore, dust from the mountain slopes induce ice accretion - due to the presence of freezing nucleus. Freezing nucleus, any particle that, when present in a mass of supercooled water, will induce growth of an ice crystal about itself; most ice crystals in the atmosphere are thought to form on freezing nuclei. learning.explanation: FRONTS In a standard polar front depression, there are two distinct fronts which travel alongside the low pressure zone. The warm front leads the cold front. In the warm front, there is cold air ahead, and the new warm air is flowing towards it, and, due to the reduced air density, rides above the cold air. This forces the new air upwards, and causes multiple levels of cloud to form. At the lower levels, these clouds are heavy enough to contain rain. Warm fronts are also not very aggressive, and they have quite a shallow gradient of 1:150. This means that the band of rain lasts for a very long distance ahead of the front (with no rain after the front), whereas cold fronts force the warmer air ahead upwards, and are more aggressive, with a much steeper gradient, and therefore a shorter band of rain. Cold fronts have a steeper gradient of betweeen 1:50 and 1:100.

content.question: Considering the North Atlantic region between 30°N and 65°N, the mean position of the polar front during summer extends from:

key_points: The polar front is the junction between the Ferrell (tropical air mass) and Polar cells (polar air mass)
At this low-pressure zone, relatively warm, moist air of the Ferrel Cell runs into relatively cold, dry air of the Polar cell

In the Northern hemisphere: Warm air mass (Tropical airmass) => South; Cold air mass (Polar air mass) => North In the northern hemisphere, the position of the polar front is affected by the seasons: During winter it typically moves to lower latitudes (further south - between 40ºN and 50ºN)
learning.explanation: The polar front is the junction between the Ferrell (tropical air mass) and Polar cells (polar air mass). At this low-pressure zone, relatively warm, moist air of the Ferrel Cell runs into relatively cold, dry air of the Polar cell. In the Northern hemisphere: Warm air mass (Tropical airmass) => South; Cold air mass (Polar air mass) => North In the northern hemisphere, the position of the polar front is affected by the seasons: During winter it typically moves to lower latitudes (further south - between 40ºN and 50ºN). Spans from Florida towards the Southern part of Ireland and UK, then curves in a SE direction towards the Northern part of the Black Sea. During SUMMER it is situated further north, closer to the poles (between 50ºN and 65ºN). Spans from Newfoundland (North-Eastern Canada) towards Ireland and UK. Turns towards North of Scotland and continues towards Gulf of Botnia (60º - 65ºN). In the southern hemisphere, the polar front remains almost constant regardless of the season (50ºS).

content.question:
Refer to figure.
An airport broadcasts the following METAR:
23008KT 4500 DZ -BR OVC006 15/13 Q1009
The figure shows a cross-section of a frontal system. At which location is the airport most likely to be situated?

key_points: The figure shows a warm front followed by a cold front, a cross section of a very common polar front depression (travelling low)
We always look at the fronts like this, with them travelling from left to right on the page
The forward front is a shallower sloped warm front
learning.explanation: The figure shows a warm front followed by a cold front, a cross section of a very common polar front depression (travelling low). We always look at the fronts like this, with them travelling from left to right on the page. The forward front is a shallower sloped warm front. The steeper front at the back is the cold front. In the warm front, there is cold air ahead, and the new warm air is flowing towards it, which, due to the reduced air density, rises above the cold air. This forces the air upwards, and causes multiple levels of cloud to form. At the lower levels, these clouds are heavy enough to contain rain. Location 1 is after the cold front, where the visibility should be good, and there will be gradually rising clouds above, the remnants of the convective clouds, and maybe some altostratus or cirrus. The other weather conditions will be dependent on the specific air mass properties. Location 2 is just ahead of a cold front, which aggressively forces air to rise, and sets off heavy showers of rain and, in an unstable atmosphere, convective active and cumulonimbus clouds. At location 3, once the warm front has cleared, the weather is that of a warm sector, inside which, the weather is very much dependent on season, the conditions of the source region, and the track of the air mass. In summer, the warm sector will often see good weather and some fair weather cumulus clouds, but moreso will have stable air, stratified clouds, drizzle, light rain and mist in the winter. This would line up with the METAR in the question. At location 4, in the lower layers of a warm front, Nimbostratus clouds cause a wide band of rain and heavy rain ahead of the front, and then as the clouds reach close to the ground, drizzle and frontal fog can begin to form. The lack of heavy rain is the biggest indicator that it is NOT location 1, where heavy rain is pretty much garaunteed.

content.question: Which of the following conditions is most likely to produce severe thunderstorms, severe low-level turbulence, heavy showers of rain, and hail?

options.A: A slow-moving warm front over warm land in the summer.
options.B: A fast-moving cold front over warm land in the summer.
options.C: A fast-moving warm front over cold sea in the summer.
options.D: A slow-moving cold front over cold land in the winter.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: A similar question can be found in our database under the reference number 508178
The questions are different, due to the options
In this question, the fast moving cold front over warm land is more "aggressive" than the slow moving cold front over cold land
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: A similar question can be found in our database under the reference number 508178. The questions are different, due to the options. In this question, the fast moving cold front over warm land is more "aggressive" than the slow moving cold front over cold land. Slower cold fronts (called "active" cold fronts) tend to contain more weather as we have eluded to in our explanation for question 508178, but the warm land would likely have a greater effect on the weather than the speed of the front. Immediately we can see that the most likely location for these types of highly convective weather is going to be on the steeper cold front (instead of a warm front), the more aggressive of the two simple weather fronts. Yes, a warm occlusion will include a bit of cold front at altitude, but as it is a warm occlusion, the majority of it acts as a warm front. During summer, the presence of a swiftly advancing cold front over warm land can create highly unstable conditions, leading to moderate to severe turbulence and the development of thunderstorms with substantial rainfall and hail. Additionally, this fast-moving cold front has the potential to generate severe squall line thunderstorms, occurring along or ahead of the actual front.

These move eastwards along the semi stationary front “Polar front” which is located between 35ºN and 65ºN (higher latitudes in Summer, lower in Winter). An air mass is simply a large portion of air in the Earth's atmosphere, defined by where it has been "formed" (a high pressure, stable source region where it develops its initial characteristics) and the track it has taken to get somewhere. For Western Europe, the air masses are classified as T(Tropical), P(Polar) and A(Arctic) - in terms of their thermal qualities - and c(continental) or m(maritime) - in terms of their water content. Note that Artic air is from directly North of Europe, whereas Polar air is from the Polar cell fo the atmosphere, so source regions like Siberia or Northern Canada/Greenland. The Polar front splits Sub-tropical air (which we refer to as Tropical for European air masses) from Polar air. Therefore, when a Polar front depression forms (in the North Atlantic specifically), the warm sector to the South of the depression is that Tropical air, whereas the rest of the depression is surrounded by the Polar air. Therefore, in this question; (1) is Tropical air in the warm sector, (2) is Polar air ahead of the depression (East), and (3) is the Polar air behind the depression (West). (4) is a little more complicated. It is the air North of the depression. From the options, we have already narrowed down the correct answer, and that states that the air North of the depression "may be" Arctic. This is not always the case, but certainly possible, especially in Winter when Artic air can easily flow down from the North Pole. Often, for a new depression, this air would also be Polar, but later down the life cycle, it can drag Artic air down to it. Also, the question says "may be", rather than "is", which we are happy to consider as being correct.

When a polar front approaches a mountain range in southern Europe, the expected weather conditions can vary. However, there are some general patterns that can be observed. Typically, as the polar front encounters the mountain range, it is forced to rise due to the barrier presented by the mountains. As the air rises, it cools and condenses, leading to the formation of clouds and precipitation. The precipitation can be in the form of rain, snow, or a mix of both, depending on the altitude and temperature. The interaction between the polar front and the mountain range can result in significant weather changes. Some of the common weather conditions associated with this scenario include: Increased precipitation: The forced ascent of the air along the mountain range can lead to enhanced precipitation, potentially causing heavy rainfall or snowfall. Thunderstorms: The lifting of warm and moist air along the mountain range can contribute to the development of thunderstorms, especially if there is a strong contrast in air masses. Rapid weather changes: The passage of the polar front can bring about rapid shifts in weather conditions, with alternating periods of rain, sunshine, and possibly even dramatic temperature fluctuations.

Occurs at a warm front or occlusion

The fog can form along a belt up to 200 NM wide which then travels with the front. - unless the front is a very slow moving one, the fog is typically present for only about 2 to 3 hours. The denser cold air displaces/overtakes the less dense warm air => cold air will slide itself under the warm air, forcing it to rise. The slope of a cold front is approximately 1:50 to 1:80. content.question: If you have to fly through a warm front when freezing level is at 10000 feet in the warm air and at 2000 feet in the cold air, at which altitude is the probability of freezing rain the lowest?

key_points: FREEZING RAIN
The conditions needed for freezing rain are quite specific
Generally, precipitation first falls from a cloud as snow
learning.explanation: FREEZING RAIN. The conditions needed for freezing rain are quite specific. Generally, precipitation first falls from a cloud as snow. If it falls through warmer air before reaching the ground, it can melt and turn to rain droplets. If it then falls through cold air again before hitting the ground, the droplets can become supercooled (which means that they are still falling in liquid state, even though their temperature is below 0ºC). As said above, freezing rain consists of raindrops that have become supercooled after falling from warmer air into air where the temperature is below zero. In this case, the danger exists between 2000ft and 10000 ft =>Therefore, at 12000 feet, you are above both freezing levels and the probability of freezing rain is zero.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct about a warm occlusion in Western Europe?

options.A: In a warm occlusion, the warm, moist tropical maritime air overrides the cold polar maritime air ahead. Precipitation and radiation fog occur ahead of the surface position of the front.
options.B: A warm occlusion is a combination of a warm and cold front. At the surface, it resembles a warm front with embedded CBs. The precipitation falls ahead of the surface position of the front.
options.C: A warm occlusion is a combination of a warm and a cold front. At the surface, it resembles a cold front with embedded CBs and heavy rain, which are located close to just behind the surface position of the front.
options.D: In a warm occlusion, the cool polar continental air mass undercuts the colder arctic maritime air mass. The rain band just ahead of the surface position of the front has embedded CBs, severe turbulence, and hail. A thick frontal fog follows the surface position of the front.

key_points: OCCLUDED FRONT
If a cold front catches up to and overtakes a warm front, the frontal boundary created between the two air masses is called and occluded front
When the cold front catches up with the warm front, the warm sector is lifted
learning.explanation: OCCLUDED FRONT. If a cold front catches up to and overtakes a warm front, the frontal boundary created between the two air masses is called and occluded front. When the cold front catches up with the warm front, the warm sector is lifted. WARM OCCLUSION: the air ahead of the warm front is colder than the air behind the cold front. The cold air behind the cold front rises over colder air ahead of the warm front. The "less cold" air rises over the leading colder air. This forces the cold front aloft (It "climbs up" the back of the warm front). Warm, moist and unstable air is lifted. The warm front acts as normal, but the extra cold front forces air upwards, causing embedded CBs (they are embedded within the usual warm front clouds). COLD OCCLUSION: the air behind the cold front is colder than the air ahead of the warm front. The cold air behind the cold front undercuts the less cold air ahead of the warm front. Warm front aloft. Warm, moist and stable air is lifted. To go through each option: "In a warm occlusion, the warm, moist tropical maritime air overrides the cold polar maritime air ahead. Precipitation and radiation fog occur ahead of the surface position of the front." Whilst this is partially correct, it refers to a warm front ONLY, and also says radiation fog, which is not correct even for a warm front itself. "A warm occlusion is a combination of a warm and cold front. At the surface, it resembles a warm front with embedded CBs. The precipitation falls ahead of the surface position of the front." Correct. As can be seen in the explanation and figures above, a warm occlusion is both a warm and a cold front, with exactly these characteristics. "A warm occlusion is a combination of a warm and a cold front. At the surface, it resembles a cold front with embedded CBs and heavy rain, which are located close to just behind the surface position of the front." Incorrect. At the surface it resembles a warm front (the warm front is the one that reaches the ground), and the precipitation occurs in front of the where the front meets the ground. "In a warm occlusion, the cool polar continental air mass undercuts the colder arctic maritime air mass. The rain band just ahead of the surface position of the front has embedded CBs, severe turbulence, and hail. A thick frontal fog follows the surface position of the front." Incorrect, there is no "undercutting" in a warm occlusion. All the air rises over the leading air, as the leading air is the coldest (and therefore most dense).

content.question: How can the precipitation area be described near a quasi-stationary front?

options.C: A wide area on the cold-air side and sometimes patchy along the line of the front itself.

key_points: A STATIONARY front forms when a cold front or warm front stops moving
This happens when two masses of air are pushing against each other but neither is powerful enough to move the other
The situation can be described winds blowing parallel to the front instead of perpendicular can help it stay in place
learning.explanation: A STATIONARY front forms when a cold front or warm front stops moving. This happens when two masses of air are pushing against each other but neither is powerful enough to move the other. The situation can be described winds blowing parallel to the front instead of perpendicular can help it stay in place. The exact weather of a stationary front depends greatly on the characteristics of its constituent air masses - their moisture levels, for example - and the general instability of the local atmosphere. Often, however, conditions resemble those encountered along warm front weather: extensive cloudiness and continuous rain. A wide area of precipitation can be expected on the cold-air side. Since there is little frontal movement, weather conditions are likely to be comparatively quiet, though longer lasting.

content.question:
The following changes are observed when a front has passed in the Northern Hemisphere...
Wind: Sharp veer.
Clouds: Embedded CBs.
Pressure: Stops decreasing at the lowest value.
Visibility: Very poor.
What kind of front and airmass is it?

key_points: WARM FRONT
Warm air replacing cold air

The warm air is forced to rise over the cold air as part of slowly pushing the cold air out of the way Conditions associated with a warm front: Surface winds: A change in wind direction is commonly observed with the passage of any front
learning.explanation: WARM FRONT. Warm air replacing cold air. The warm air is forced to rise over the cold air as part of slowly pushing the cold air out of the way Conditions associated with a warm front: Surface winds: A change in wind direction is commonly observed with the passage of any front. Before the front arrives, winds ahead of the front (in the colder air mass) are typically from the South/South-West, but once the front passes through, winds usually veer around, and come from the West/South-West (in the warmer air mass). The wind veering actually tells us nothing, as all standard Northern Hemisphere fronts cause the wind to veer. Temperature: steady before the front. An increase is usually observed at the front. Behind the warm front, it is steady again. Pressure: As the front approaches, the pressure gradually decreases. Then once the front passes, the pressure should remain constant, at the lowest pressure value(whilst within the warm sector). Clouds: As a warm front approaches, the clouds can be expected to begin at high levels about 500 nm ahead of the front, gradually reducing to the ground as the front passes. In stable air, you can expect Cs, Ci, As, Ns, St and some frontal fog. In unstable air, the rising warm air can trigger convective activity, such as Cu or Cb, with a good chance of the CBs being embedded in the surrounding clouds (as mentioned in this question). Precipitation: Heavy rain can be expected ahead of the front. Thunderstorms can occur if the airmass is unstable. The rain tends to turn into drizzle as the front passes. Visibility: Generally poor, due to the potential for fog and drizzle, but this can vary quite a lot depending on the air masses involved. => The real indicators in this question are the pressure (stops reducing), meaning a warm front, and the embedded CBs meaning unstable air.

content.question: Which cloud poses the highest risk to aviation safety during a cold front?

key_points: When cold air displaces warm air, it creates a cold front
On synoptic charts, cold fronts are represented by blue triangles
Clouds: In contrast to warm fronts, cold fronts often bring about a rapid development of clouds, typically occurring 50-100 km ahead of the surface position of the front
learning.explanation: When cold air displaces warm air, it creates a cold front. On synoptic charts, cold fronts are represented by blue triangles. Clouds: In contrast to warm fronts, cold fronts often bring about a rapid development of clouds, typically occurring 50-100 km ahead of the surface position of the front. These clouds include AC (Altocumulus) and CC (Cirrocumulus) clouds, followed by a sudden appearance of CU (Cumulus) and CB (Cumulonimbus) clouds. These cloud formations are often associated with moderate to severe turbulence. Precipitation: Showers of rain, which can be heavy at times, are generated by CU and CB clouds along the cold front. Depending on the intensity and season, these showers can manifest as rain, snow, or hail, and there is also the possibility of thunderstorms forming. Visibility: Showery precipitation along the cold front typically leads to a reduction in visibility, which can be significant during heavy precipitation and snowfall. However, once the front passes, visibility improves considerably as the falling precipitation helps cleanse the air, removing impurities.

Conditions associated with a cold front: Surface winds: Sudden change in wind direction is commonly observed with the passage of a cold front. Before the front arrives, winds ahead of the front (in the warmer air mass) are typically out of the southwest, but once the front passes through, winds usually shift around to the northwest (in the colder air mass). Temperature: steady before the front. A sudden decrease is usually observed at the front. Behind the cold front, it remains steady (cold). Pressure: before the front, it decreases slightly. At the front it starts to rise (after reaching its lowest value). A slow increase is observed behind the front. Clouds: At the cold front, BKN to OVC layers may occur with CU and CB. However, if the air is stable cold fronts can also produce nimbostratus clouds (and stratocumulus, and stratus clouds.) Precipitation: heavy rain or snow showers can be expected. Along with thunderstorms and hail, if the air is unstable. Visibility: good, except in precipitation. => Considering the above, we can conclude a cold front in stable atmosphere is being described.

content.question: A mountain range spans from North to South. A warm front from the West is passing over the mountains, with rain and a cloud ceiling of 2 000 ft. What is the expected weather at an airfield situated on the eastern side of the mountains?

options.A: Cloud base higher than 2 000 ft and colder air than on the Western side of the mountain chain.
options.B: Cloud base lower than 2 000 ft and colder air than on the Western side of the mountain chain.
options.C: Cloud base lower than 2 000 ft and warmer air than on the Western side of the mountain chain.
options.D: Cloud base higher than 2 000 ft and warmer air than on the Western side of the mountain chain.

key_points: This question is a little tricky as it is asking about the effect of the warm front, not the foehn effect
The warm front means that the air in front of the warm front is colder than the air that comes after the warm front
The warmer air behind rides up over the cooler air in front, creating the slanted front
learning.explanation: This question is a little tricky as it is asking about the effect of the warm front, not the foehn effect. The warm front means that the air in front of the warm front is colder than the air that comes after the warm front. The warmer air behind rides up over the cooler air in front, creating the slanted front. This slant means that the cloud base drops as the front gets closer to a position. With a few hundred miles to go before the front passes overhead, you can expect high level cirrus clouds, followed by lowering clouds of cirrostratus, altostratus, nimbostratus (rain clouds), and finally low level stratus with some fog and stratus fractus. In relation to this question then, the front is travelling from West to East, so the front is passing over the western faces of the mountains, which will have a very low cloud base and rain/fog. The Eastern faces, however, have yet to be passed over, so will have a higher cloud base than 2 000 ft, and are in the cold sector, so the temperature will be lower there also. There are a few questions that exist similar to this, but without the presence of the warm front. This makes them affected more so by the foehn effect, which is where the windward side of the mountains gets rained on, reducing the moisture in the air, so the air is drier and warmer on the lee-side. The passing of a warm front is a much larger event, and is therefore enough to negate any such temperature change due to the foehn effect.

The front is quite weak and the width of the precipitation band is 20 NM. The aircraft is equipped with serviceable anti-icing and de-icing systems. The pilot does NOT have a valid instrument rating, therefore the flight has to be made in VMC.

options.A: Fly on the cold-air side of the front just below the altitude of the freezing level of the air on the warm side.
options.B: Stay at least 5 NM ahead of the front clear of the clouds and don't cross the front.
options.C: Traverse the warm front perpendicular to its direction of movement and fly below the freezing level.
options.D: Fly below the clouds and above the freezing level on the cold-air side because any precipitation encountered in this area will NOT adhere to the airframe.

key_points: The most dangerous part of a warm front is the potential for a "rain-ice triangle" to form
That is where the warm sector air above the frontal surface precipitates raindrops that are warmer than 0°C, into an area that is colder than 0°C

If an aircraft is within that cold sector, then the airframe will be below freezing temperature, and the droplets will be around 0°C, which will then freeze upon hitting the airframe, causing one of the most dangerous types of ice accumulation, rain-ice
learning.explanation: The most dangerous part of a warm front is the potential for a "rain-ice triangle" to form. That is where the warm sector air above the frontal surface precipitates raindrops that are warmer than 0°C, into an area that is colder than 0°C. If an aircraft is within that cold sector, then the airframe will be below freezing temperature, and the droplets will be around 0°C, which will then freeze upon hitting the airframe, causing one of the most dangerous types of ice accumulation, rain-ice. Rain-ice builds up incredibly quickly on all parts of the upper surface of the wing, not just the leading edge, meaning that standard anti-ice and de-icing systems are only partially effective, and often completely overpowered by the ice accretion. As warm fronts are very shallow, rain ice triangles are very wide but not usually very tall, in this case only 1000 ft. This means that the best way to avoid them is to fly above or beneath the region in which they can occur. Also, it is best to fly perpendicular to the front (therefore parallel to its direction of movement), so the rain-ice triangle danger can be passed through as quickly as possible, rather than staying near it for unnecessarily long. Unfortunately, this is not possible as there will most likely be clouds in the warm sector at the level that is being flown (the pilot is VMC only), and the pilot has to traverse the warm sector anyway within the cold sector to reach their destination. In the case of this pilot who is licensed for VMC flight only, they cannot climb into the NS clouds above, and should instead remain under 1000 ft (the freezing level in the cold sector) to remain out of the rain-ice triangle. It is useful to note that there is a chance of ice pellets at this altitude, as the raindrops may have frozen on their descent. This is still far better than being inside the region of freezing rain.

content.question: When planning an IFR flight, the pilot notices that there is a warm front on his/her route. It is not possible to fly around it and the performance of the aircraft does not allow to climb over it. How should he/she plan his/her route?

options.A: Plan his/her route through the warm front on the shortest way possible.
options.C: Descend low as possible, staying at 500 ft AGL, even if it means flying below MSA and entering IMC.
options.D: Fly along searching for an opening.

key_points: Refer to figure Ahead of a warm front, freezing rain can be encountered
Freezing Rain occurs when precipitation, in the form of rain, passes from a warm air mass into a relative cold air mass of an air temperature less than 0°C
The rain maintaining its liquid state in sub-zero temperatures renders it super-cooled
learning.explanation: Refer to figure Ahead of a warm front, freezing rain can be encountered. Freezing Rain occurs when precipitation, in the form of rain, passes from a warm air mass into a relative cold air mass of an air temperature less than 0°C. The rain maintaining its liquid state in sub-zero temperatures renders it super-cooled. It can cause significant accumulations of Clear Ice. Clear ice is the most hazardous form of airframe icing, because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. When the supercooled drop hits the airframe, it freezes relatively slowly due to the latent heat released in the freezing process. This allows part of the drop to spread backwards before it too freezes. Now, let's analyse each option individually: "Fly along searching for an opening." and "Orbit and wait for improvement.". Incorrect. The question states that the pilot is in the planning phase, it does not make sense to plan an orbit. In such circumstances, it is safer and cost-effective to delay the departure. Furthermore, flying along the front trying to find an opening is rarely an option due to fuel available and airspace restrictions. "Descend low as possible, staying at 500 ft AGL, even if it means flying below MSA and entering IMC." Incorrect. MSA stands for minimum sector altitude, an aircraft must not descend below the local MSA. "Plan his/her route through the warm front on the shortest way possible." Correct. This is the most correct option available. Avoid any signs of precipitation.

learning.explanation: An air mass is a large volume of air where the humidity and temperature in the horizontal are fairly uniform. It has, therefore, a homogeneous nature. The temperature and humidity properties are obtained by the air remaining roughly stationary over a surface where conditions are constant for some length of time (High Pressure). Occurs at a warm front or occlusion
The main cause – precipitation lowering the cloud base to the ground
learning.explanation: FRONTAL FOG. Occurs at a warm front or occlusion. The main cause – precipitation lowering the cloud base to the ground. content.question:
According to cyclogenesis, place the following parts of the life cycle of a polar front depression in order.
1. Mature stage
2. Initial stage (Frontogenesis)
3. Dying stage
4. Occluded stage

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.06.02.08.01: Describe the movements of fronts and pressure systems and the life cycle of a mid-latitude depression. A mid latitude depression (also called a polar front depression, or a travelling low), is a key part of the global climate and air circulation pattern. It sits on the "Polar Front", which is the front between the cold Polar Cell and the warmer Ferrel Cell of the atmosphere, somewhere between 30° and 70° N/S, depending on the season. From here on we will discuss it in relation to the Northern Hemisphere, but just reverse the North and South directions for the Southern Hemisphere Polar Front. To the North of the Polar Front sits the high pressure zone of the North Pole and the very cold Arctic Circle. To the South of the Polar front sits the subtropical high pressure belt (the Azores high in the Atlantic). This means that the air wants to flow towards the Polar Front from both directions (pressure gradient force), but the air turns right due to the Coriolis effect, so the wind to the North of the front is East-to-West and the air to the South of the front is West-East. This scenario is unstable, and gives rise to travelling lows. Refer to the annex above - it uses different names for the stages. Initial stage (Frontogenesis) - The first stage is triggered by a small change in circumstances, the triggers are many, but are not important. The warm air mass begins to push into the cold air mass, creating a kink in the previously non-moving Polar Front. Mature Stage - This is where the cold sector begins to "fight back", and develops a cold front to claim back some of the land from the warm sector. The depression usually reaches its lowest pressure in this stage, and this stage can last for a good few days. It brings the familiar view of a cold front "chasing a warm front". Occluded Stage - The cold front has now caught up to the warm front at the centre of the depression, where the weather appears to look like both fronts pass together. Here, the warm sector no longer reaches the ground, and has been lifted into the air in this region. The fronts continue to occlude, and act like a clothing zipper, "zipping up" from the base out towards the edge. Dying Stage - The fronts are now almost completely occluded, and the depression is beginning to "fill in" with pressure. The whole system is beginning to collapse and the warm sector which initially invaded has become isolated from the rest of the warm air to the south, and is forced upwards into the atmosphere where it will disperse. A few things can happen here, including back-bent occlusions, and secondary depressions which may continue to develop. The dying stage is often accelerated by the depression moving over land, where the air has more friction with the land, and there is no longer a steady source of moisture beneath to feed the system. Through this whole life cycle, the system is moving towards the East (with some North/South movement according to the Jetstream, Polar Front, etc.), as the wind in the warm sector controls the direction.

Which option correctly places, in a chronological order, the four stages of a mid-latitude depression life cycle? The stages are named and described as follows:
Occlusion: the cold front has caught up with the warm front, the warm air has been partially lifted up.
Developed: fronts are well defined, there is a pronounced warm sector.
Cyclogenesis: a disturbance and fall in pressure causes cyclonic circulation.
Frontolysis: all the warm air has been lifted up.

key_points: Note: There is one count of unverified feedback in the comments that indicated the answer could be different in the UK CAA exams
We cannot see how this is possible, so please send us any further feedback you may have about this, thank you! Mid Latitude Depression development 1
CYCLOGENESIS STAGE – this is known as the initial stage of the cyclone’s life cycle
learning.explanation: Note: There is one count of unverified feedback in the comments that indicated the answer could be different in the UK CAA exams. We cannot see how this is possible, so please send us any further feedback you may have about this, thank you! Mid Latitude Depression development 1. CYCLOGENESIS STAGE – this is known as the initial stage of the cyclone’s life cycle. In this stage, a boundary separates opposing fronts of cold and warm air. When an upper level disturbance moves over the front, it causes a wave to form. Cyclonic shear begins to happen when the warm and cold fronts slide against each other => which generates the spinning motion characteristic of cyclones. 2. DEVELOPED/MATURE STAGE – during this stage, the wave formed during the initial phase grows as warm air replaces the space left behind by moving the cold front. The cold front moves faster than the warm front, intensifying the cyclonic circulation. 3. OCCLUDED STAGE - In the mid-latitude cyclone’s third stage, the denser cold front catches up with the warm front. Because the warm air isn’t dense enough to displace the cold air ahead of it, it shifts up and slides above the cold air in its path. This action eventually forms an occluded front, in which the wave transforms into a loop, which is narrower at its base and cuts off the supply of warm air. 4. DISSOLVING/ FRONTOLYSIS STAGE - The final stage of the cyclone occurs when the loop formed by the cold front boundary surrounding the low-pressure pocket of warm air closes. This cuts off the supply of warm moist air and the lifting force caused by the interaction between the cold and warm fronts. The loss of the convergence and uplift mechanisms cause the cyclone to dissolve, and the low pressure system gradually stabilizes.

We always look at the fronts like this, with them travelling from left to right on the page. The forward front is a shallower sloped warm front. The steeper front at the back is the cold front. In the warm front, there is cold air ahead, and the new warm air is flowing towards it, which, due to the reduced air density, rises above the cold air. This forces the air upwards, and causes multiple levels of cloud to form. At the lower levels, these clouds are heavy enough to contain rain. At location 4, in the lower layers of a warm front, Nimbostratus clouds cause a wide band of rain and heavy rain ahead of the front, and then as the clouds reach close to the ground, drizzle and frontal fog can begin to form. This would line up with the METAR in the question. At location 3, once the warm front has cleared, the weather is that of a warm sector, inside which, the weather is very much dependent on season, the conditions of the source region, and the track of the air mass. In summer, the warm sector will often see good weather and some fair weather cumulus clouds, but moreso will have stable air, stratified clouds, drizzle, light rain and mist in the winter. Location 2 is just ahead of a cold front, which aggressively forces air to rise, and sets off heavy showers of rain and, in an unstable atmosphere, convective active and cumulonimbus clouds. Location 1 is after the cold front, where the visibility should be good, and there will be gradually rising clouds above, the remnants of the convective clouds, and maybe some altostratus or cirrus. The other weather conditions will be dependent on the specific air mass properties.

options.A: In summer, the warm front is often accompanied by freezing rain or freezing drizzle close to the surface. In winter, the icing conditions close to the surface are less severe than in the summer, due to the lower moisture content of the air.

options.C: In winter, the temperature difference between the two air masses is smaller than in the summer, and therefore the average upper winds are weaker than in the summer.

key_points: Warm front clouds form a distinctive pattern as a warm front approaches
These clouds typically appear 800-1 000 km ahead of the surface position of the warm front
The sequence of cloud types you can observe starts with CI (cirrus clouds), then progresses to CS (cirrostratus), AS (altostratus), and finally NS (nimbostratus) along with low-level stratus clouds
learning.explanation: Warm front clouds form a distinctive pattern as a warm front approaches. These clouds typically appear 800-1 000 km ahead of the surface position of the warm front. The sequence of cloud types you can observe starts with CI (cirrus clouds), then progresses to CS (cirrostratus), AS (altostratus), and finally NS (nimbostratus) along with low-level stratus clouds. Notably, the cloud base tends to lower as the warm front draws near. While it's rare, unstable warm fronts can occasionally feature CB (cumulonimbus) clouds, bringing associated hazards. Let's examine each option separately: "In summer, the warm front is often accompanied by freezing rain or freezing drizzle close to the surface. In winter, the icing conditions close to the surface are less severe than in the summer, due to the lower moisture content of the air." Incorrect. In fact, winter is the season when warm fronts are more commonly associated with freezing rain or drizzle due to the lower temperatures. "In summer, the warm fronts are in most cases accompanied with heavy showers of rain and severe thunderstorms, produced by embedded Ns clouds." Incorrect. While thunderstorms can occur with unstable warm fronts, they are usually not produced by embedded nimbostratus clouds (Ns). Cumulonimbus (CB) clouds are more likely sources of thunderstorms in such cases. "In winter, the temperature difference between the two air masses is smaller than in the summer, and therefore the average upper winds are weaker than in the summer." Incorrect. In winter, the temperature difference between the two air masses is typically greater, which can result in stronger upper-level winds compared to the summer.

learning.explanation: The warm front slopes forward. The lighter, warmer, moist air is forced up and over the heavier, colder air, rising very gently along a slope of about 1:150. This gentle slope results in minimal vertical flow, leading to stratiform clouds and light to moderate continuous drizzle, rain, or snow along the warm front. In contrast, the cold front slopes backward because the heavy, cold air forces itself underneath the warmer, lighter air. With a slope of between 1:50 and 1:80, the cold front is steeper than the warm front but still relatively gentle, causing stratiform clouds due to the gentle uplift. However, the cold front also has a bulging "cold nose" near the surface, creating an unstable area where warm, buoyant air lies beneath cold air. This instability triggers rapid vertical uplift, resulting in large cumuliform clouds.

content.question: What weather conditions are likely to occur when cold, dry polar air moves towards the warmer, humid ocean surface just to the south of Australia?

key_points: Each region has its own climatology, which includes what air masses it gets, and from where they come
We are not required to know the air masses for Australia in the syllabus, but we do need to understand broadly how air masses cause different types of weather
When a cold air mass advects over a warmer surface (Polar air moving towards the tropics, for example), the lower layers of air are heated by the ground, which creates instability
learning.explanation: Each region has its own climatology, which includes what air masses it gets, and from where they come. We are not required to know the air masses for Australia in the syllabus, but we do need to understand broadly how air masses cause different types of weather. When a cold air mass advects over a warmer surface (Polar air moving towards the tropics, for example), the lower layers of air are heated by the ground, which creates instability. It can be though of that the low level warm air wants to rise through the cold air, which is an unstable air mass. That is not exactly how it works, but is a good way to remember it. If air were to move from a warm source region to a colder area of surface, the warm air would be cooled from below, creating a stable air mass. It can be thought of like this; the cold air is more than happy to sit below a warmer air mass, so remains stable. Instability causes cumuliform clouds, which cause rain to fall as showers and storms, whereas stability tends to create stratiform clouds and fog, with rain falling lighter but more continuously. Cold Polar air moving over Australia is a cold air mass moving over a warmer surface, so will cause instability and showers.

content.question: Flying near which type of weather front produces the highest likelihood of encountering thunderstorms, CBs and convective clouds?

key_points: Immediately we can see that the most likely location for these types of highly convective weather is going to be on the steeper cold front (instead of a warm front), the more aggressive of the two simple weather fronts
Yes, a warm occlusion will include a bit of cold front at altitude, but as it is a warm occlusion, the majority of it acts as a warm front
This leaves us with a fast-moving cold front and a slow-moving cold front
learning.explanation: Immediately we can see that the most likely location for these types of highly convective weather is going to be on the steeper cold front (instead of a warm front), the more aggressive of the two simple weather fronts. Yes, a warm occlusion will include a bit of cold front at altitude, but as it is a warm occlusion, the majority of it acts as a warm front. This leaves us with a fast-moving cold front and a slow-moving cold front. This is slightly counterintuitive, as one might think that a fast moving cold front is likely to be more "aggressive" than a slow-moving one, but it is actually the opposite. Meteorologists call slow-moving cold fronts "active cold fronts". This is because their slower movement means that the associated uplift is more gradual, and with a slightly shallower slope, gives rise to a much wider band of convective clouds, thunderstorms, precipitation and turbulence, going up the side of the front, which spreads the weather over a long distance. fast-moving cold fronts are referred to as "inactive cold fronts". This is a bit of a misnomer, as they still cause plenty of aggressive uplift, which leads to significant bands of thunderstorms and heavy convection in unstable atmospheric conditions, but the band of thunderstorms is much thinner, and remains ahead of the front (not up the sloped side of the front like slow-moving cold fronts). This is why the answer is that thunderstorms, CBs and convective clouds are more likely to be encountered at and around a slow-moving cold front.

In the warm front, there is cold air ahead, and the new warm air is flowing towards it, which, due to the reduced air density, rises above the cold air. Point 2 is just ahead of a cold front, which aggressively forces air to rise, and sets off heavy showers of rain and, in an unstable atmosphere, convective active and cumulonimbus clouds. content.question:
Which of the following statements is true with regards to occlusions over Europe?
1. A cold occlusion is followed by a rapid clearance in the weather and a drop in temperature.
2. A warm occlusion is followed by a rapid clearance in the weather and a significant increase in temperature.
3. Cold occlusions primarily affect Europe during the summer and most of the associated precipitation occurs behind the surface position.

key_points: An occluded front is formed when a cold front and a warm front merge together
Usually, a cold front will catch up with the preceding warm front, and the warm sector of air will be trapped, and lifted up from the surface
An occlusion usually takes on the form of both fronts in quick succession, and the weather in the central part of the occlusion will be decided by the type of occlusion, warm or cold
learning.explanation: An occluded front is formed when a cold front and a warm front merge together. Usually, a cold front will catch up with the preceding warm front, and the warm sector of air will be trapped, and lifted up from the surface. An occlusion usually takes on the form of both fronts in quick succession, and the weather in the central part of the occlusion will be decided by the type of occlusion, warm or cold. The type of occlusion is simply which front stays connected to the ground. If the warm front remains intact, and the cold front "rides" up it, then the warm front is still touching the ground, and it is a warm occlusion. The frontal weather acts more like a warm front in this case, and the majority of the rain occurs before the front hits, and the weather will gradually clear after the surface front has passed. On the other hand, if the cold front forces the warm front up, then the occlusion is a cold occlusion. This acts more like a cold front. Cold fronts are responsible for strong, severe storms. The weather tends to exhibit a dip in temperature prior to the storms and a drastic change in wind direction and speed. After the front passes, there is usually a rapid clearance in the weather. The type of occlusion depends on which sector of air is coldest. Of course, the warmest sector is forced upwards in between two colder sectors of air. If the back sector is coldest, then it will be a cold occlusion. If the front section is the coldest, then the back section will be comparatively warm, and a warm occlusion will form. In Europe, we usually see cold occlusions in Summer and warm occlusions in Winter (the opposite temperature of the season). This is because the winds into Western Europe are from the Atlantic and, in Summer, the ground is warmer than the water, so the front sector (which has already reached ground) is warmer than the back sector (still over water), and therefore a cold occlusion is most common.

An aircraft flying through a front which is moving in the opposite direction will experience the wind veering. Conversely, if the aircraft is moving in the same direction as the front, the wind will back. Conditions When the Cold Front has Passed. After the frontal passage, the towering cumulus and cumulonimbus clouds begin to dissipate to cumulus clouds with a corresponding decrease in precipitation. Good visibility eventually prevails, temperatures remain cooler and the barometric pressure continues to rise.
