content.question: During Summer, monsoon in India, the trade winds change from _____ to _____.

key_points: During the summer months (June, July, August), the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) tends to shift away from the Equator and move further northward
As a result, the SE trade winds originating from the Southern Hemisphere undergo a change in direction as they cross the geographic Equator and enter the Northern Hemisphere
The Coriolis force deflects these winds to the right in the Northern Hemisphere (opposite to the left deflection in the Southern Hemisphere), causing them to become SW monsoons
learning.explanation: During the summer months (June, July, August), the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) tends to shift away from the Equator and move further northward. As a result, the SE trade winds originating from the Southern Hemisphere undergo a change in direction as they cross the geographic Equator and enter the Northern Hemisphere. The Coriolis force deflects these winds to the right in the Northern Hemisphere (opposite to the left deflection in the Southern Hemisphere), causing them to become SW monsoons. This phenomenon is observed in various regions of the Northern Hemisphere, including parts of Africa, India, and Southeast Asia. In the context of India, these SW monsoons bring humid maritime air. Conversely, during the winter months (December, January, February), the ITCZ tends to move further south, particularly over land areas. As a result, the NE trade winds from the Northern Hemisphere need to cross the geographic Equator to reach the ITCZ. Upon entering the Southern Hemisphere, the Coriolis force deflects these winds to the left, resulting in a change in their direction from NE to NW. Consequently, the Southern Hemisphere experiences NW monsoons, particularly in southern parts of Africa, while the Northern Hemisphere encounters NE monsoons in regions that previously experienced SW monsoons during the summer months (such as parts of Africa and India). Using India as an example, these NE monsoons bring dry continental air.

content.question: A Foehn wind occurs on the:

options.A: windward side of a mountain range and is caused by surface heating.
options.B: leeward side of a mountain range and is caused by the condensation level being lower on the leeward side than on the windward side.
options.C: leeward side of a mountain range and is caused by significant moisture loss by precipitation from cloud.
options.D: windward side of a mountain range and is caused by surface cooling and reverse air flow.

key_points: FOEHN EFFECT Foehn winds are warm and dry, gusty winds that periodically descends the leeward slopes of nearly all mountains and mountain ranges (warm katabatic wind)
This is a change from wet and cold conditions one side of a mountain, to warmer and drier conditions on the other (leeward) side
- How does it form? When air is forced upwards over elevated terrain, it expands and cools adiabatically (at the DALR) until it saturates
learning.explanation: FOEHN EFFECT Foehn winds are warm and dry, gusty winds that periodically descends the leeward slopes of nearly all mountains and mountain ranges (warm katabatic wind). This is a change from wet and cold conditions one side of a mountain, to warmer and drier conditions on the other (leeward) side. - How does it form? When air is forced upwards over elevated terrain, it expands and cools adiabatically (at the DALR) until it saturates. After saturation, it will continue to cool at the SALR. Since colder air can hold less water vapour, moisture condenses to form clouds and precipitates as rain/snow above the mountain’s upwind slopes. By the time it reaches the peaks and stops climbing, the air is quite dry. As the air makes its leeward descent, it is compressed and warms rapidly all the way downslope – because there is little water left to evaporate. Thus, the air is warmer and drier when it reaches the leeward slope than when it begins its windward ascent. On the windward side we can expect low cloud and precipitation whilst on the leeward side we will see clear turbulent conditions.

key_points: The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is a broad zone of air mass sometimes called the heat equator
Here, the prevailing trade winds of the North and South Hemispheres collide
Due to intense solar heating near the equator, the warm, moist air is forced up into the atmosphere
learning.explanation: The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is a broad zone of air mass sometimes called the heat equator. Here, the prevailing trade winds of the North and South Hemispheres collide. Due to intense solar heating near the equator, the warm, moist air is forced up into the atmosphere. As the air rises, it cools, causing persistent bands of showers and storms around the Earth’s midsection. these convective storms are known to produce intense rainfall, severe turbulence, severe icing, hail, lightning and windshear. The rising air mass finally subsides in what is known as the horse latitudes (between 30° - 40°N), where the air moves downward toward Earth’s surface, forming a high pressure surface region with clear, warm weather. Storms within the ITCZ will often go as high as 50 - 60 000 ft, so cannot be escaped upwards by commercial jet aircraft, and must be avoided using lateral deviations. Note: there can be a tropical jetstream flowing from East to West over the Equator region in the Indian Ocean and Central Africa, however, it is usually <100kts, and much lighter than all other jet streams. It would also likely be higher than FL390 due to the very high tropopause in that region.

content.question: The main icing zone in the ITCZ is located between:

key_points: The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is the broad zone of separation between the air masses either side of the heat equator
Here, the prevailing trade winds of the northern hemisphere blow to the southwest and collide with the southern hemisphere’s driving northeast trade winds
Due to intense solar heating near the equator, the warm, moist air is forced up into the atmosphere
learning.explanation: The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is the broad zone of separation between the air masses either side of the heat equator. Here, the prevailing trade winds of the northern hemisphere blow to the southwest and collide with the southern hemisphere’s driving northeast trade winds. Due to intense solar heating near the equator, the warm, moist air is forced up into the atmosphere. As the air rises, it cools, causing persistent bands of showers and storms around the Earth’s midsection. The main feature of the ITCZ is extensive Cu, Cb and thunderstorms. When stable air exists, there will be extensive sheets of As & Ns cloud and more continuous type rain. The rising air mass finally subsides in what is known as the horse latitudes (between 30° - 40°N), where the air moves downward toward Earth’s surface. ITCZ = doldrums = Thermal Equator = Equatorial Trough The ITCZ can vary from 25 NM to 300 NM in width and there is no well defined frontal surface. Clouds are not caused by air mass temperature differences as at the polar front, but by convergence of the NE and SE trade winds which are normally the same temperature. The cloud tops are sometimes as low as 20 000 ft but more frequently 50 000 ft or more. Turbulence is usually severe, as is icing, which can be from 16 000 ft upwards.
